title: Getting Started with bboutools
text: annual recruitment boreal caribou population typically estimated annual calf:cow ratios. bboutools fits Binomial recruitment model annual counts calves, cows, yearlings, unknown adults potentially, bulls. user ensure data surveys conducted time year, calf survival expected similar adult survival.

title: Getting Started with bboutools
text: function bb_fit_recruitment() fits Bayesian recruitment model. start month biological year (.e., ‘caribou year’) can set year_start argument. default, start month April. Data aggregated biological year (calendar year) prior model fitting. adult female proportion can either fixed estimated counts cows bulls (.e., Cows ~ Binomial(adult_female_proportion, Cows + Bulls)). user provides value adult_female_proportion, fixed. default value 0.65, accounts higher mortality males (Smith 2004). adult_female_proportion = NULL, adult female proportion estimated data (.e., Cows ~ Binomial(adult_female_proportion, Cows + Bulls)). default, biologically informative prior Beta(65,35) used. corresponds expected value 65%. yearling calf female proportion can set sex_ratio. default value 0.5. model can fit random effect year, fixed effect year /continuous effect year (.e., year trend). min_random_year argument dictates minimum number years dataset required fit random year effect; otherwise fixed year effect fit. recommended fit random year effect fewer 5 years (Kery Schaub 2011). continuous fixed effect year can fit year_trend = TRUE. user can set quiet = FALSE argument see messages sampling progress.
code: recruitment <- bb_fit_recruitment(bboudata::bbourecruit_a, year_start = 4, year_trend = TRUE, quiet = TRUE)

title: Getting Started with bboutools
text: Model convergence can checked glance() function. Model convergence provides indication whether parameter estimates reliable. Convergence considered successful default rhat < 1.05. rhat threshold can adjusted user. rhat evaluates whether chains agree values. total variance chains shrinks average variance within chains, r-hat approaches 1. Output glance() also includes ess (Effective Sample Size), represents length chain (.e., number iterations) sample independent one . default, bboutools Bayesian method saves 1,000 MCMC samples three chains (discarding first halves). number samples saved can adjusted niters argument. niters set, user can simply increment thinning rate required achieve convergence (.e., decreasing rhat).
code: glance(recruitment) #> Registered S3 method overwritten by 'mcmcr': #>   method         from  #>   as.mcmc.nlists nlist #> # A tibble: 1 × 8 #>       n     K nchains niters nthin   ess  rhat converged #>   <int> <int>   <int>  <int> <dbl> <int> <dbl> <lgl>     #> 1    27     4       3   1000    10   993  1.00 TRUE

title: Getting Started with bboutools
text: Various generic functions bboutools can used summarize interrogate output model fitting functions. coef() tidy() provide tidy table coefficient estimates. estimates() provides list coefficient estimates. augment() provides data used. model_code() provides model code BUGS-like syntax. plot() provides traceplots individual parameters. user can exclude individual random effect estimates coefficient output. Keep mind reference ‘Year’ ‘Annual’ summary outputs represent caribou year, can set user within fitting functions.
code: tidy(recruitment, include_random_effects = FALSE) #> # A tibble: 3 × 4 #>   term    estimate  lower   upper #>   <term>     <dbl>  <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1 b0       -1.46   -1.63  -1.29   #> 2 bYear    -0.0979 -0.258  0.0696 #> 3 sAnnual   0.326   0.188  0.517

title: Getting Started with bboutools
text: general, weakly informative priors used default (Gelman, Simpson, Betancourt 2017; McElreath 2016). default prior distribution parameter values can accessed bb_priors_recruitment() bb_priors_survival(). See priors vignette information. default prior distribution adult_female_proportion Beta(65, 35) default prior distribution intercept (b0) Normal(-1.5, 1), log scale. user can change priors providing named vector priors argument model fitting functions. names must match one names bb_priors_recruitment(). example, less informative priors adult_female_proportion (e.g., Beta(1, 1)) b0 (e.g., Normal(0, 5)) can supplied follows. user interested fitting models without prior information, see bb_fit_recruitment_ml() bb_fit_survival_ml(), use Maximum Likelihood approach (see details ).
code: bb_priors_recruitment() #>                         b0_mu                         b0_sd  #>                            -1                             5  #>                      bYear_mu                      bYear_sd  #>                             0                             2  #>                    bAnnual_sd                  sAnnual_rate  #>                             5                             1  #> adult_female_proportion_alpha  adult_female_proportion_beta  #>                            65                            35 recruitment <- bb_fit_recruitment(bboudata::bbourecruit_a, priors = c(adult_female_proportion_alpha = 1, adult_female_proportion_beta = 1, b0_mu = 0, b0_sd = 5))

title: Getting Started with bboutools
text: annual survival boreal caribou population typically estimated monthly fates collared adult females. bboutools fits Binomial monthly survival model number collared females mortalities. user can choose whether include individuals uncertain fates certain mortalities. function bb_fit_survival() fits Bayesian survival model. survival model always fit random intercept month. Otherwise, year_start, year_trend, min_random_year arguments behaviour bb_fit_recruitment() . include_uncertain_mortalities = TRUE, total mortalities sum certain mortalities uncertain mortalities (‘MortalitiesCertain’ ‘MortalitiesUncertain’ columns); otherwise, certain mortalities used fit model.
code: survival <- bb_fit_survival(bboudata::bbousurv_a, year_start = 4, quiet = TRUE) tidy(survival, include_random_effects = FALSE) #> # A tibble: 3 × 4 #>   term    estimate  lower upper #>   <term>     <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 b0         4.46  4.16   4.8   #> 2 sAnnual    0.327 0.0325 0.675 #> 3 sMonth     0.278 0.0608 0.669

title: Getting Started with bboutools
text: Maximum Likelihood (ML) models can fit using bb_fit_recruitment_ml() bb_fit_survival_ml() functions. functions take seconds execute Nimble must compile model C++ code. See Nimble documentation information comparison TMB. Similar Bayesian model fits, generic functions (e.g., tidy(), glance() augment()) work ML fit objects (class ‘bboufit_ml’). ML estimates comparable estimates derived equivalent Bayesian models . general, ML models can interpreted Bayesian models uninformative (e.g., uniform) priors (McElreath 2016). functionality bboutools generate predictions (.e., derived parameters) ML models. However, functionality get confidence intervals predictions. straightforward task Bayesian models.  Note ML models can struggle converge sparse data, especially fixed year effect. issues arise, user can try estimating year random effect, continuous effect (year_trend), fitting Bayesian model. Another possible source convergence issues initial values. default, bboutools sets initial values based default priors used parameters Bayesian models. user can replace initial values parameters using inits.
code: recruitment_ml <- bb_fit_recruitment_ml(bboudata::bbourecruit_a, year_start = 4, year_trend = TRUE, quiet = TRUE) glance(recruitment_ml) #> # A tibble: 1 × 4 #>       n     K loglik converged #>   <int> <int>  <dbl> <lgl>     #> 1    27     2  -90.1 TRUE survival_ml <- bb_fit_survival_ml(bboudata::bbousurv_a, year_start = 4, quiet = TRUE) tidy(recruitment_ml, include_random_effects = FALSE) #> # A tibble: 2 × 4 #>   term  estimate  lower   upper #>   <chr>    <dbl>  <dbl>   <dbl> #> 1 b0      -1.43  -1.53  -1.33   #> 2 bYear   -0.112 -0.211 -0.0128 tidy(survival_ml, include_random_effects = FALSE) #> # A tibble: 3 × 4 #>   term    estimate  lower upper #>   <chr>      <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 b0         4.45  4.17   4.73  #> 2 sAnnual    0.336 0.133  0.846 #> 3 sMonth     0.238 0.0714 0.796 bb_predict_survival(survival_ml) #> # A tibble: 32 × 6 #>    PopulationName CaribouYear Month estimate lower upper #>    <chr>                <int> <int>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #>  1 A                     1985    NA    0.873    NA    NA #>  2 A                     1986    NA    0.883    NA    NA #>  3 A                     1987    NA    0.83     NA    NA #>  4 A                     1988    NA    0.89     NA    NA #>  5 A                     1989    NA    0.875    NA    NA #>  6 A                     1990    NA    0.871    NA    NA #>  7 A                     1991    NA    0.878    NA    NA #>  8 A                     1992    NA    0.891    NA    NA #>  9 A                     1993    NA    0.868    NA    NA #> 10 A                     1994    NA    0.842    NA    NA #> # ℹ 22 more rows growth <- bb_predict_growth(survival_ml, recruitment_ml) bb_plot_year_growth(growth) inits_ml <- bb_fit_recruitment_ml(bboudata::bbourecruit_a, inits = c(b0 = 1, sAnnual = 0.3))

title: Getting Started with bboutools
text: bb_fit_survival() bb_fit_recruitment() functions use Bayesian approach return objects inherit class bboufit. Objects class bboufit four elements: model - compiled Nimble model created nimble::nimbleModel(). model_code - model code text format. samples - MCMC samples generated fromnimble::runMCMC() converted object class mcmcr. data - survival recruitment data provided. raw materials exploration analysis. example, view trace density plots plot(fit$samples). See mcmcr mcmcderive working mcmcr objects, convert samples object class mcmc.list, e,g, coda::.mcmc.list working coda R package. bb_fit_survival_ml() bb_fit_recruitment_ml() functions use Maximum Likelihood approach return objects inherit class bboufit_ml. Objects class bboufit_ml five elements: model - Nimble model created nimble::nimbleModel(). model_code - model code text format. mle - Maximum Likelihood output created model$findMLE(). summary - summary Maximum Likelihood output created model$summary(mle). data - survival recruitment data provided. See nimble work nimble model objects Maximum Likelihood output.

title: Analytic Methods for Estimation of Boreal Caribou Survival, Recruitment and Population Growth
text: survival model annual random effect trend specified simplified form BUGS language readability. model code used Bayesian frequentist methods.
code: b0 ~ Normal(3, 10) bYear ~ Normal(0, 2)  sMonth ~  Exponential(1) for(i in 1:nMonth)  bMonth[i] ~ Normal(0, sMonth)  sAnnual ~ Exponential(1) for(i in 1:nAnnual)  bAnnual[i] ~ Normal(0, sAnnual)  for(i in 1:nObs) {   logit(eSurvival[i]) = b0 + bMonth[Month[i]] + bAnnual[Annual[i]] + bYear * Year[i]   Mortalities[i] ~ Binomial(1 - eSurvival[i], StartTotal[i]) }

title: Analytic Methods for Estimation of Boreal Caribou Survival, Recruitment and Population Growth
text: recruitment model annual random effect year trend specified simplified form BUGS language readability. Group-level observations aggregated caribou year prior model fitting. frequentist approach, demographic stochasticity removed model possible estimate discrete latent variables using Laplace approximation. minimal effect estimates. adjusted model demographic stochasticity specified .
code: b0 ~ Normal(-1, 5) bYear ~ Normal(0, 1)  adult_female_proportion ~ Beta(65, 35)  sAnnual ~  Exponential(1) for(i in 1:nAnnual)  bAnnual[i] ~ Normal(0, sAnnual)  for(i in 1:nAnnual) {   FemaleYearlings[i] ~ Binomial(sex_ratio, Yearlings[i])   Cows[i] ~ Binomial(adult_female_proportion, CowsBulls[i])   OtherAdultsFemales[i] ~ Binomial(adult_female_proportion, UnknownAdults[i])   log(eRecruitment[i]) <- b0 + bAnnual[Annual[i]] + bYear * Year[i]   AdultsFemales[i] <- max(FemaleYearlings[i] + Cows[i] + OtherAdultsFemales[i], 1)   Calves[i] ~ Binomial(eRecruitment[i], AdultsFemales[i]) } bYear ~ Normal(0, 1)  adult_female_proportion ~ Beta(65, 35)  sAnnual ~  Exponential(1) for(i in 1:nAnnual)  bAnnual[i] ~ Normal(0, sAnnual)  for(i in 1:nAnnual) {   Cows[i] ~ Binomial(adult_female_proportion, CowsBulls[i])   FemaleYearlings[i] <- round(sex_ratio * Yearlings[i])   OtherAdultsFemales[i] <- round(adult_female_proportion * UnknownAdults[i])   logit(eRecruitment[i]) <- b0 + bAnnual[Annual[i]] + bYear * Year[i]   AdultsFemales[i] <- max(FemaleYearlings[i] + Cows[i] + OtherAdultsFemales[i], 1)   Calves[i] ~ Binomial(eRecruitment[i], AdultsFemales[i]) }

what: Predicted Survival, Recruitment and Population Growth
title: Analytic Methods for Estimation of Boreal Caribou Survival, Recruitment and Population Growth
text: ungulate populations generally polygynous survival recruitment estimated respect number adult (mature) females. estimate recruitment following DeCesare et al. (2012), predicted annual calves per female adult first divided two give expected number female calves per adult female (assumption 1:1 sex ratio). R_F = R/2 Next annual recruitment adjusted give proportional change population. R_\Delta =  \frac{R_F}{1 + R_F} rate population growth (\lambda) \lambda = \frac{N_{t+1}}{N_t} N_t population abundance year t. Following Hatter Bergerud (1991), can shown \lambda = \frac{S}{1-R} S annual survival. \lambda calculated R_\Delta S \lambda = \frac{S}{1-R_\Delta} reliable estimates may produced Integrated Population Model (IPM). See example methods used Lamb et al. (2024). However, IPM beyond scope software requires estimates abundance N, typically available jurisdictions.

title: Prior Selection and Influence
text: Given full model, expected survival probability ^{th} year j^{th} month \text{logit}(Survival[,j]) = b0 + bAnnual[] + bMonth[j] + bYear \cdot Year[] bAnnual can fixed random effect categorical year intercept log-odds scale Year scaled continuous year. model following default priors bboutools Intercept (log-odds scale) b0 \sim Normal(3, sd = 10) Year fixed effect bAnnual[] \sim Normal(0, sd = 10) Year random effect sAnnual \sim Exponential(1) \\ bAnnual \sim Normal(0, sd = sAnnual) Month random effect sMonth \sim Exponential(1)\\ bMonth \sim Normal(0, sd = sMonth) Year continuous effect bYear \sim Normal(0, sd = 2)

title: Prior Selection and Influence
text: Given full model, expected recruitment (calves per adult female) ^{th} year logit(Recruitment[]) = b0 + bAnnual[] + bYear \cdot Year[] bAnnual can fixed random effect categorical year intercept log scale Year scaled continuous year. model following default priors bboutools Intercept (log-odds scale) b0 \sim Normal(-1, sd = 5) Categorical year fixed effect bAnnual[] \sim Normal(0, sd = 5) Categorical year random effect sAnnual \sim Exponential(1)\\ bAnnual \sim Normal(0, sd = sAnnual) Continuous year effect bYear \sim Normal(0, sd = 2) recruitment model can also estimate adult female proportion observed Cows Bulls Cows = adult\_female\_proportion \cdot (Cows + Bulls) default prior adult\_female\_proportion mode 65% adult\_female\_proportion \sim Beta(65, 35)

title: Prior Selection and Influence
text: example influence priors parameter estimates, tighten standard deviation fixed effect categorical year intercept monthly survival probability. equivalent maximum likelihood model also fit comparison.  Bayesian model vague priors (default) annual survival estimates closely match Maximum Likelihood estimates, whereas Bayesian model tighter prior year fixed effect standard deviation results estimates pulled toward mean. behaviour desirable (.e., place less trust extreme estimates), model year random effect can fit. another example, user might strongly believe (.e., based literature biological understanding) true adult female proportion 65%. compare estimates informative, informative (default) vague priors adult\_female\_proportion, along maximum likelihood estimates.  example, adult female proportion estimate Bayesian model vague priors closely matches Maximum Likelihood estimate, whereas Bayesian model informative prior gives less weight data. adult\_female\_proportion can also simply fixed. See bb_fit_recruitment() details.
code: library(bboutools) library(dplyr) library(ggplot2) set.seed(1) data <- bboudata::bbousurv_c  # force model to fit fixed year effect, use default priors fit <- bb_fit_survival(data,   min_random_year = Inf,   quiet = TRUE )  # tighten prior on bAnnual by changing SD from default 10 to 1 fit_prior <- bb_fit_survival(data,   min_random_year = Inf, quiet = TRUE,   priors = c("bAnnual_sd" = 1) )  # fit maximum likelihood model for comparison fit_ml <- bb_fit_survival_ml(data,   min_random_year = Inf,   quiet = TRUE ) set.seed(1) data <- bboudata::bbourecruit_c fit <- bb_fit_recruitment(data,   adult_female_proportion = NULL,   quiet = TRUE )  fit_inf <- bb_fit_recruitment(data,   adult_female_proportion = NULL,   quiet = TRUE,   priors = c(     "adult_female_proportion_alpha" = 650,     "adult_female_proportion_beta" = 350   ) )  fit_vague <- bb_fit_recruitment(data,   adult_female_proportion = NULL,   quiet = TRUE,   priors = c(     "adult_female_proportion_alpha" = 1,     "adult_female_proportion_beta" = 1   ) )  fit_ml <- bb_fit_recruitment_ml(data,   adult_female_proportion = NULL,   quiet = TRUE )

text: bboutools accepts survival data single population specific format. survival model, includes random effect month, fitted using bb_fit_survival(). achieve convergence increase nthin. Predictions can generated using bb_predict_survival(). plotted using bb_plot_year()  survival month can plotted using bb_plot_month()  estimates represent annual survival rate month lasted whole year.
code: library(tibble) # for printing data frames library(ggplot2) # for plotting  library(bboudata) # for boreal caribou datasets #>  #> Attaching package: 'bboudata' #> The following object is masked from 'package:bboutools': #>  #>     licensing_md library(bboutools)  surv_data <- bboudata::bbousurv_a head(surv_data) #> # A tibble: 6 × 6 #>   PopulationName  Year Month StartTotal MortalitiesCertain MortalitiesUncertain #>   <chr>          <int> <int>      <int>              <int>                <int> #> 1 A               1986     1          0                  0                    0 #> 2 A               1986     2          8                  0                    0 #> 3 A               1986     3          8                  0                    0 #> 4 A               1986     4          8                  0                    0 #> 5 A               1986     5          8                  0                    0 #> 6 A               1986     6          8                  0                    0 set.seed(99) surv_fit <- bb_fit_survival(surv_data, quiet = TRUE) glance(surv_fit) #> # A tibble: 1 × 8 #>       n     K nchains niters nthin   ess  rhat converged #>   <int> <int>   <int>  <int> <dbl> <int> <dbl> <lgl>     #> 1   363     5       3   1000    10   111  1.03 TRUE surv_pred <- bb_predict_survival(surv_fit) surv_pred #> # A tibble: 32 × 6 #>    PopulationName CaribouYear Month estimate lower upper #>    <chr>                <int> <int>    <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #>  1 A                     1985    NA    0.872 0.762 0.947 #>  2 A                     1986    NA    0.881 0.791 0.952 #>  3 A                     1987    NA    0.841 0.645 0.908 #>  4 A                     1988    NA    0.887 0.813 0.96  #>  5 A                     1989    NA    0.874 0.785 0.943 #>  6 A                     1990    NA    0.872 0.785 0.936 #>  7 A                     1991    NA    0.877 0.801 0.936 #>  8 A                     1992    NA    0.889 0.822 0.956 #>  9 A                     1993    NA    0.87  0.793 0.927 #> 10 A                     1994    NA    0.849 0.756 0.909 #> # ℹ 22 more rows bb_plot_year_survival(surv_pred) +   expand_limits(y = c(0, 1)) bb_plot_month_survival(surv_fit)

title: Boreal Caribou Survival, Recruitment and Population Growth
text: function bb_predict_growth() predicts annual population growth (lambda) rate survival recruitment models.  bb_predict_population_change() calculates population change (%) uncertainty cumulative product population growth.
code: lambda <- bb_predict_growth(surv_fit, recruit_fit) bb_plot_year_growth(lambda) change <- bb_predict_population_change(surv_fit, recruit_fit) bb_plot_year_population_change(change)

title: Fit Recruitment Model — bb_fit_recruitment
text: Fit heirarchical Bayesian recruitment model using Nimble.

title: Fit Recruitment Model — bb_fit_recruitment
code: bb_fit_recruitment(   data,   adult_female_proportion = 0.65,   sex_ratio = 0.5,   min_random_year = 5,   year_trend = FALSE,   year_start = 4L,   nthin = 10,   niters = 1000,   priors = NULL,   quiet = FALSE )

title: Fit Recruitment Model — bb_fit_recruitment
text: data data.frame. adult_female_proportion number 0 1 expected proportion adults female. NULL, proportion estimated data (.e., Cows ~ Binomial(adult_female_proportion, Cows + Bulls)) prior dbeta(65, 35) used. prior can changed via priors argument. sex_ratio number 0 1 proportion females birth. proportion applied yearlings. min_random_year whole number minimum number years required fit year random effect (opposed fixed effect). year_trend flag indicating whether fit year trend effect. Year trend fit also fixed year effect (opposed random effect). year_start whole number 1 12 indicating start caribou (.e., biological) year. default, April set start caribou year. nthin whole number thinning rate. niters whole number number iterations per chain thinning burn-. priors named vector parameter prior distribution values. missing values assigned default values priors_survival() priors_recruitment(). NULL, parameters assigned default priors. quiet flag indicating whether suppress messages progress bars.

title: Fit Recruitment Model — bb_fit_recruitment
text: list Nimble model object, data mcmcr samples.

title: Fit Recruitment Model — bb_fit_recruitment
text: number years > min_random_year, fixed-effects model fit. Otherwise, mixed-effects model fit random intercept year. year_trend TRUE number years > min_random_year, model fit year continuous effect (.e. trend) fixed effect year. year_trend TRUE number years <= min_random_year, model fit year continuous effect random intercept year. start month Caribou year can adjusted year_start.

title: Fit Recruitment Model — bb_fit_recruitment
code: if (interactive()) {   fit <- bb_fit_recruitment(bboudata::bbourecruit_a) }

title: Recruitment model default priors — bb_priors_recruitment

text: data data.frame. year_random flag indicating whether include year random effect. FALSE, year fitted fixed effect. year_trend flag indicating whether fit year trend effect. text: Parameter Descriptions bboutools Functions

title: Parameter Descriptions for bboutools Functions — params
text: ... Unused parameters. data data.frame. x object. object object. string column indicating group derive predictions . conf_level number 0 1 confidence level. include_random_effects flag indicating whether include random effects coefficient table. Standard deviation estimates always included. estimate function calculate estimate. min_random_year whole number minimum number years required fit year random effect (opposed fixed effect). year_trend flag indicating whether fit year trend effect. Year trend fit also fixed year effect (opposed random effect). include_uncertain_morts flag indicating whether include uncertain mortalities total mortalities. adult_female_proportion number 0 1 expected proportion adults female. NULL, proportion estimated data (.e., Cows ~ Binomial(adult_female_proportion, Cows + Bulls)) prior dbeta(65, 35) used. prior can changed via priors argument. sex_ratio number 0 1 proportion females birth. year flag indicating whether predict year. month flag indicating whether predict month. nthin whole number thinning rate. niters whole number number iterations per chain thinning burn-. priors named vector parameter prior distribution values. missing values assigned default values priors_survival() priors_recruitment(). NULL, parameters assigned default priors. inits named vector parameter initial values. missing values assigned default value 0. NULL, parameters assigned default value 0. survival object class 'bboufit_survival' (output bb_fit_survival()). recruitment object class 'bboufit_recruitment' (output bb_fit_recruitment()) quiet flag indicating whether suppress messages progress bars. term string term name. sig_fig whole number significant figures round estimates . original_scale flag indicating whether return estimates original scale. year_random flag indicating whether include year random effect. FALSE, year fitted fixed effect. year_start whole number 1 12 indicating start caribou (.e., biological) year. default, April set start caribou year. rhat number greater 1 maximum rhat value required model convergence. params named list parameter names values simulate.

title: bboutools 1.0.0
text: cleaned documentation following JOSS review. add Stable lifecycle badge.

title: bboutools 0.1.0
text: added rhat argument glance() converged() adjust convergence threshold, default value 1.05. Convergence longer depends ess. removed exclude_year argument bb_fit_survival_ml() failure fit fixed year effect resolved intercept adjustment. provide warning user start caribou year (year_start) matching survival recruitment model fits bb_predict_growth().

title: bboutools 0.0.0.9007
text: Added bb_predict_calf_cow_ratio() bb_predict_recruitment() now predicts adjusted recruitment, following methods DeCesare (2012). Previous output bb_predict_recruitment() can now obtained running bb_predict_calf_cow_ratio(). Renamed yearling_proportion_female argument bb_fit_recruitment() sex_ratio. matches bbouretro language arguments bb_predict_recruitment(). Changed default value include_uncertain_morts argument bb_fit_survival() TRUE. matches default behaviour bbouretro. Added article ‘Prior Selection Influence’. Added example “Analytical Methods” article.

title: bboutools 0.0.0.9006
text: Moved internal data checking functions exported function bboudata. Updated bbtutorial vignette mention new data checking functions.

title: bboutools 0.0.0.9005
text: bb_fit_recruitment() error NA values PopulationName, Year, Month Day columns. bb_fit_survival() error NA values PopulationName, Year, Month, StartTotal, MortalitiesCertain MortalitiesUncertain columns.

title: bboutools 0.0.0.9004
text: Added ‘Getting Started’ vignette. Added functions: bb_predict_survival_trend() bb_predict_recruitment_trend() bb_plot_year_trend_survival() bb_plot_year_trend_recruitment() bb_predict_population_change() bb_plot_year_population_change() plot() (plot traceplots bboufit object) Added arguments: year_start = 4L bb_fit_survival() bb_fit_recruitment() set caribou year start month integer - (default April) yearling_female_proportion = 0.5 bb_fit_recruitment() set yearling sex ratio year_trend = FALSE bb_fit_survival() bb_fit_recruitment() fit model year trend include_random_effects = TRUE coef()/tidy() provide possibility removing individual random effect estimates

title: bboutools 0.0.0.9003
text: Switch MCMC engine Jags Nimble. bb_fit_survival_ml() bb_fit_recruitment_ml Added summary methods Maximum Likelihood output class ‘bboufit_ml’. Changed priors passed fit functions (e.g. priors = c(b0_mu = 4, b0_sd = 2) instead priors = list(b0 = "dnorm(4, 2^-2)")). Added argument sig_fig coef()/tidy()/predict() methods round estimates lower/upper bounds set significant figures.

title: bboutools 0.0.0.9002
text: bb_predict_growth() now handles different years doesn’t return month. Adjusted default priors.

title: bboutools 0.0.0.9001
text: Soft-deprecated bb_predict_lambda() bb_predict_growth(). Added bb_plot_year_growth(). Added bb_plot_year_recruitment(). Added bb_plot_month_survival(). Added bb_plot_year_survival(). Added bb_plot_month().

title: bboutools 0.0.0.9000
text: Added NEWS.md file track changes package.
